message.content: This question requires knowledge about the properties of water and how it behaves in different depths of the ocean. As a person goes deeper into the ocean, the weight of the water above them increases, creating higher pressure. This is known as water pressure or hydrostatic pressure. So, when the person reaches a darker part of the ocean, there is actually more weight or pressure on them. Option (A) is incorrect because as one goes deeper into the ocean, less sunlight reaches that depth, resulting in less light and darker conditions. Option (C) is also incorrect because the amount of salt in the ocean does not change significantly with depth. Option (D) is unrelated and not related to the properties of the ocean.

This question requires basic knowledge about the ocean and how sunlight penetrates through water. As a person goes deeper into the ocean, there is less sunlight reaching them. Therefore, in a darker part of the ocean, there is less sunlight, contradicting option (A). Option (C) is unrelated because the salt concentration in the water does not change significantly with depth. Option (D) is irrelevant and not related to the properties of the ocean. Option (B) is the correct answer because as a person goes deeper into the ocean, there is an increase in water pressure, creating more weight on their body.

Option (A) is incorrect because the deeper they go, the less sunlight penetrates through the water, leading to a darker environment. Option (C) is incorrect because the salinity of the ocean water remains relatively consistent regardless of depth. Option (D) is unrelated and not based on any scientific principles.

The correct answer is (B) because as a person goes deeper into the ocean, the water exerts more pressure, causing an increase in weight on the person.
